summary: Email correspondence between a U.S. Attorney's Office prosecutor and a U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) Task Force Officer regarding travel records for Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein. The CBP officer confirms the provided TECS travel records for Maxwell and Epstein are complete for the 1990-2000 period, as outbound travel was not systematically recorded then, and offers records post-2000. The emails discuss verifying travel for three individuals and include a spreadsheet of Maxwell's crossings.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Her travel records (TECS) are being reviewed by the U.S. Attorney's Office, with note of name variations (with/without space in surname). An attached spreadsheet chronologically lists her border crossings.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: His travel records (TECS) are being reviewed by the U.S. Attorney's Office alongside Ghislaine Maxwell's.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney
persons.context: The email sender from the U.S. Attorney's Office in New York who is seeking CBP travel records for a case, coordinating calls, and confirming searches for three individuals.

persons.name: U.S. Customs and Border Protection Task Force Officer - SDNY
persons.context: The officer responds to the prosecutor's inquiry, explains limitations of pre-2000 outbound travel records, provides Maxwell's consolidated travel spreadsheet, and offers further assistance.

connections.description: Their travel records are being reviewed together by prosecutors, indicating their linked activities are under investigation.

connections.person2: U.S. Customs and Border Protection Task Force Officer - SDNY
connections.description: Law enforcement and legal professionals collaborating on a case, with the prosecutor requesting travel data and the CBP officer providing analysis and records.

events.title: CBP Travel Records Gap
events.description: U.S. Customs and Border Protection confirms outbound travel records were not systematically recorded in their database (TECS) during this period, limiting available data.

events.title: Travel Records Request and Coordination
events.description: Email exchange where an Assistant U.S. Attorney requests a call and provides records to a CBP Task Force Officer to discuss travel history questions for a case.
personsInvolved: U.S. Customs and Border Protection Task Force Officer - SDNY

events.title: CBP Travel Analysis Provided
events.description: CBP Task Force Officer responds with analysis, confirming TECS records for Maxwell and Epstein are complete for 1990-2000 and providing a consolidated spreadsheet of Maxwell's crossings.
personsInvolved: U.S. Customs and Border Protection Task Force Officer - SDNY

keyFacts: CBP travel records for Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein were limited for 1990-2000 because outbound travel was not systematically recorded in the TECS database during that era.
Maxwell's travel records had two variations due to her surname being recorded with and without a space, requiring separate TECS records.
The U.S. Attorney's Office was investigating the travel history of three individuals (including Maxwell and Epstein) as part of a case in July 2021.
The correspondence is marked Law Enforcement Sensitive/For Official Use Only, indicating the ongoing sensitivity of the investigation.
A CBP Task Force Officer compiled a chronological spreadsheet of Maxwell's border crossings to assist prosecutors in reviewing her travel history.
